image.altText: A grid of three images of lidia thorpe speaking outside, and two men one wearing a white shirt and the other a camouflage hat

items.synopsis: Two notorious Australian Neo-Nazis are exposed as the likely architects of a menacing video in which a masked man denigrates Indigenous senator Lidia Thorpe before burning the Aboriginal flag.

title.children: A hidden timestamp on a 'menacing' Neo-Nazi video aimed at Lidia Thorpe indicates who the likely architects are

image.altText: A young woman wearing a coordinated crochet set sits on a beach buggy

items.synopsis: Ahuva Maizel last spoke to her daughter early on Saturday. It was a brief phone call that has led to an unbearable wait for the family, who fear the 21-year-old has been kidnapped by Hamas militants.

title.children: Adi was dancing in the desert with friends. When Hamas advanced, she made one phone call

image.altText: US President Joe Biden, in a suit and tie, speaks at a podium gesturing with his hands. Kamala Harris and a US flag stand behind

items.synopsis: Death tolls are rising in Israel and Gaza, as the US prepares to send its top diplomat to Israel to show its support and offer further assistance.

title.children: Biden calls Hamas attack 'sheer evil', as death tolls rise in Israel and Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fears are growing that the conflict could expand beyond Gaza, with Israel also facing wider threats and shared hostility from other non-state actors. Nicholas Blanford, a non-resident senior fellow with the Atlantic Council's Middle East Programs, told ABC Radio Hezbollah was a very real and formidable threat to Israel. "It's a very close ally of the Hamas movement.. so what is going in Gaza now has a direct impact on Hezbollah," he said. While the two groups are different the two share many similarities especially when it comes to shared hostility towards Israel. "In fact, the unprecedented operation Hamas conducted on Saturday breaking out of the Gaza, and entering the Israeli settlements around Gaza was straight out of Hezbollah's playbook," he said speaking from Beirut. "A massive rocket barrage, infiltration on mass across the border to cause as much damage and chaos as possible inside Israel. "Hezbollah have been training since 2007 but in this case it was Hamas which put it into practice with deadly effect." But he noted Hezbollah faced constraints with shots still being called by Iran so if the group was told to go to all-out war with Israel they would. But he also said he wasn’t certain Hezbollah would want to face an all-out conflict knowing it would erode is “potent capabilities” further down the road.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas attack was 'right out of Hezbollah's playbook'

children.content: Fears are growing that the conflict could expand beyond Gaza, with Israel also facing wider threats and shared hostility from other non-state actors.
Nicholas Blanford,
a non-resident senior fellow with the Atlantic Council's Middle East Programs, told ABC Radio
Hezbollah
was a very real and formidable threat to Israel.
"It's a very close ally of the Hamas movement..
so what is going in Gaza now has a direct impact on Hezbollah," he said.
While the two groups are different the two share many similarities especially when it comes to shared hostility towards Israel.

"In fact, the unprecedented operation Hamas conducted on Saturday breaking out of the Gaza, and entering the Israeli settlements around Gaza was straight out of Hezbollah's playbook," he said speaking from Beirut.
"A massive rocket barrage, infiltration on mass across the border to cause as much damage and chaos as possible inside Israel.
"Hezbollah have been training since 2007 but in this case it was Hamas which put it into practice with deadly effect."
But he noted Hezbollah faced constraints with shots still being called by Iran so if the group was told to go to all-out war with Israel they would.
But he also said he wasn’t certain Hezbollah would want to face an all-out conflict knowing it would erode is “potent capabilities” further down the road.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'm in Jerusalem, where the situation has become increasingly tense this week. There was an eerie quiet on usually bustling streets in the city's Jewish western areas on Tuesday. Meanwhile, Islamic prayers rang out from east Jerusalem as the sun set. Some hotels closed, amid security concerns and a spate of cancelled bookings. On Tuesday afternoon, Hamas fired rockets towards Israeli settlements in the Occupied West Bank, and several checkpoints into Israel were closed. The IDF said so far, 1,500 Hamas gunmen had been killed in Israel, mainly in the south. Several Israeli soliders were killed in the country's north, near the border with Lebanon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What it is like in a city on edge

children.content: I'm in Jerusalem, where the situation has become increasingly tense this week.
There was an eerie quiet on usually bustling streets in the city's Jewish western areas on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, Islamic prayers rang out from east Jerusalem as the sun set.
Some hotels closed, amid security concerns and a spate of cancelled bookings.

props.alt: A large amount of sand blocking a road.

children.content: This road near Jerusalem leading to the Occupied West Bank was blocked on Tuesday.
(ABC News)
On Tuesday afternoon, Hamas fired rockets towards Israeli settlements in the Occupied West Bank, and several checkpoints into Israel were closed.
The IDF said so far, 1,500 Hamas gunmen had been killed in Israel, mainly in the south.
Several Israeli soliders were killed in the country's north, near the border with Lebanon.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Brad Ryan in Washington DC US President Joe Biden's address, which we reported on earlier, came after a phone call with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, their third since the attack. He outlined steps being taken by the US in response to the attack, including: Providing ammunition and interceptors to replenish Israel's Iron Dome missile defence system Sharing intelligence and deploying experts to "consult with and advise" their Israeli counterparts on recovering hostages boosting US military assets in the      region "to strengthen our deterrence", such as moving a      carrier strike group with thousands of Navy personnel to the eastern      Mediterranean, and bolstering fighter aircraft numbers Mr Biden also said the US Congress, when it resumes this week, would be asked to take "urgent action" to fund the national security needs of America's critical partners. (This could be complicated by the fact the House of Representatives still has no speaker). Without naming adversaries like Iran or Hezbollah, he said: "To any country, any organisation, anyone thinking of taking advantage of this situation, I have one word: don't. "Our hearts may be broken but our resolve is clear." The president confirmed 14 American citizens were killed in the attack. "We now know that American citizens are among those being held by Hamas," he added, but did not say how many.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden outlines steps US is taking in reponse to Hamas's attack

children.content: Reporting by Brad Ryan in Washington DC
US President Joe Biden's
address, which we reported on earlier, came after a phone call with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, their third since the attack.
He outlined steps being taken by the US in response to the attack, including:
Providing ammunition and interceptors to replenish Israel's Iron Dome missile defence system
Sharing intelligence and deploying experts to "consult with and advise" their Israeli counterparts on recovering hostages

boosting US military assets in the      region "to strengthen our deterrence", such as moving a      carrier strike group with thousands of Navy personnel to the eastern      Mediterranean, and bolstering fighter aircraft numbers

Mr Biden also said the US Congress, when it resumes this week, would be asked to take "urgent action" to fund the national security needs of America's critical partners. (This could be complicated by the fact the House of Representatives still has no speaker).
Without naming adversaries like Iran or Hezbollah, he said:
"To any country, any organisation, anyone thinking of taking advantage of this situation, I have one word: don't.
"Our hearts may be broken but our resolve is clear."
The president confirmed
14 American citizens were killed
in the attack. "We now know that American citizens are among those being held by Hamas," he added, but did not say how many.

image.altText: Placard reads Aboriginal Sovereignty Never Ceded

items.synopsis: It’s become a well-used rallying cry by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people at marches and events and the term "sovereignty" has been brought up a lot throughout this referendum debate but there’s more to this term than you might realise – let's unpack it.

title.children: Have you heard the chant 'sovereignty never ceded'? Do you know what it means?

image.altText: John Farnham (left) performing and Cathy Freeman (right) smiling.

items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Wednesday, October 11.

title.children: John Farnham, Cathy Freeman and more Australians of the Year sign open letter urging Yes vote

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Garrick Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney says she is "shocked" by comments made by the Opposition leader about late Northern Territory land rights advocate, Yunupiŋu. Gumatj clan leader and former Australian of the Year Yunupiŋu died earlier this year aged 74, after a lifetime spent trying to better the outcomes of his Yolŋu people in north-east Arnhem Land. Earlier today, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton equated Yunupiŋu's work towards improving his Arnhem Land community with why a Voice to Parliament wasn't needed. "They've got a logging company, they've got a building company, they've got housing, they've got a functioning society … because of the leadership demonstrated by Yunupiŋu and others around him over the course of a long period, and that's what we want to see replicated elsewhere," he said. Mr Dutton's comments in Adelaide did not account for the fact that the East Arnhem local government area (LGA) remains one of the 10 most disadvantaged LGAs in Australia. In reaction, Ms Burney says she was "shocked at that statement". "Yunupiŋu spent his entire life fighting for his people, fighting for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people across this country and also advocating a Voice to Parliament," she said. "Quite frankly, Peter Dutton should apologise for taking the name of Yunupiŋu in vain. "The idea that there isn't disadvantage in north-east Arnhem Land is patently ridiculous. "Peter Dutton has no right at all to use the name of Yunupiŋu in that way." NOTE: Yunupiŋu's surname and image is used as per the wishes of his family.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Call for Peter Dutton to apologise over Yunupiŋu comments

children.content: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton (left) and Indigenous Australias Minister Linda Burney (right)
(ABC News)
Reporting by Matt Garrick
Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney
says she is "shocked" by comments made by the Opposition leader about late Northern Territory land rights advocate,
Yunupiŋu
Gumatj clan leader and former Australian of the Year Yunupiŋu
died earlier this year aged 74
, after a lifetime spent trying to better the outcomes of his Yolŋu people in north-east Arnhem Land.
Earlier today,
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton
equated Yunupiŋu's work towards improving his Arnhem Land community with why a Voice to Parliament wasn't needed.

"They've got a logging company, they've got a building company, they've got housing, they've got a functioning society … because of the leadership demonstrated by Yunupiŋu and others around him over the course of a long period, and that's what we want to see replicated elsewhere," he said.
Mr Dutton's comments in Adelaide did not account for the fact that the East Arnhem local government area (LGA) remains one of the
10 most disadvantaged LGAs in Australia
In reaction, Ms Burney says she was "shocked at that statement".
"Yunupiŋu spent his entire life fighting for his people, fighting for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people across this country and also advocating a Voice to Parliament," she said.
"Quite frankly, Peter Dutton should apologise for taking the name of Yunupiŋu in vain.
"The idea that there isn't disadvantage in north-east Arnhem Land is patently ridiculous.
"Peter Dutton has no right at all to use the name of Yunupiŋu in that way."
NOTE: Yunupiŋu's surname and image is used as per the wishes of his family.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Twenty five Australian of the Year recipients have penned an open letter to the public, urging them to vote Yes on Saturday. They say the Yes vote could start to repair the "devastating impact" of colonisation on the welfare of Indigenous Australians. "The effective exclusion of Indigenous voices from decision-making has been at best useless and costly and, at worst, damaging, blocking any meaningful progress," they said. "There is overwhelming evidence that, when given a voice, services are effective and lead to improvements in outcomes, as happened during the Covid pandemic." "The Voice is about ensuring that our First Nations people have a genuine say in matters that impact on their lives. "A Yes vote is a step to a more united and cohesive nation, conscious of the past and looking together to the future." Signatories of the letter include : Dylan Alcott Rosie Batty Taryn Brumfitt Rob de Castella Mick Dodson Peter Doherty John Farnham Tim Flannery Cathy Freeman Adam Gilchrist Adam Goodes Evonne Goolagong Shane Gould Richard Harris Patrick McGorry Simon McKeon David Morrison Gustav Nossal Lowitja O'Donoghue Keith Potger Dick Smith Fiona Stanley Grace Tame Fiona Wood John Yu
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Once in a lifetime opportunity': Australians of the Year write open letter urging Yes vote

children.content: John Farnham (left) and Cathy Freeman (right) have both signed the open letter.
(AAP: Joel Carrett, ABC: Helena Burke)
Twenty five Australian of the Year recipients have penned an open letter to the public,
urging them to vote Yes on Saturday
They say the Yes vote could start to repair the "devastating impact" of colonisation on the welfare of Indigenous Australians.
"The effective exclusion of Indigenous voices from decision-making has been at best useless and costly and, at worst, damaging, blocking any meaningful progress," they said.
"There is overwhelming evidence that, when given a voice, services are effective and lead to improvements in outcomes, as happened during the Covid pandemic."
"The Voice is about ensuring that our First Nations people have a genuine say in matters that impact on their lives.
"A Yes vote is a step to a more united and cohesive nation, conscious of the past and looking together to the future."
Signatories of the letter include
Dylan Alcott
Rosie Batty
Taryn Brumfitt
Rob de Castella
Mick Dodson
Peter Doherty
John Farnham
Tim Flannery
Cathy Freeman
Adam Gilchrist
Adam Goodes
Evonne Goolagong
Shane Gould
Richard Harris
Patrick McGorry
Simon McKeon
David Morrison
Gustav Nossal
Lowitja O'Donoghue
Keith Potger
Dick Smith
Fiona Stanley
Grace Tame
Fiona Wood
John Yu

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! We will be bringing you the latest developments on the Voice to Parliament referendum as they happen today. Yesterday, the AEC confirmed 3.3 million Australians had already cast their votes in the referendum. The AEC also detailed some "fairly bizarre behaviour" from a small number of voters towards staff at early voting centres. They urged voters to remain civil when heading to the polls. Speaking from Uluru, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese compared misinformation about Voice to "fake news" around apology to Stolen Generation. Stay tuned for the latest updates as they unfold today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Welcome to our live coverage

children.content: Good morning!
We will be bringing you the latest developments on the
Voice to Parliament
referendum as they happen today.
Yesterday, the AEC confirmed
3.3 million Australians had already cast their votes in the referendum
The AEC also detailed some "fairly bizarre behaviour" from a small number of voters towards staff at early voting centres. They
urged voters to remain civil when heading to the polls
Speaking from Uluru,
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
compared misinformation about Voice to "fake news" around apology to Stolen Generation.
Stay tuned for the latest updates as they unfold today.

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

items.synopsis: The trial of Canberra man accused of molesting two sisters ran for two weeks, but after a day and a half of deliberations the jury was discharged after failing to reach a verdict.

image.altText: a outback shelter with cars and charging and solar panels

image.altText: Destroyed buildings in Rimal, Gaza.

image.altText: Chinese flags near the logo Evergrande Centre in Shanghai, China, on September 24, 2021.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest trading partner is facing its biggest economic slowdown in decades, and the Reserve Bank has warned that stress in China's economy will be felt across the world — including here in Australia.

image.altText: A young woman with dark skin and black hair wearing yellow headphones looks at a yellow smartphone

items.synopsis: While some are optimistic about the streaming giant's move into audiobooks, others fear it will threaten authors' already precarious livelihoods.

image.altText: A soldier in military uniform and holding a gun stands in front of a destroyed apartment building with emergency crews.

items.synopsis: To prepare their soldiers for the psychological challenges of combat, the Ukrainian military has developed a sophisticated resilience training program. Its insights may be very valuable to other militaries — including the ADF, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Inside the Ukrainian military's resilience training, where soldiers' mental strength is a weapon

image.altText: Close up shot of a woman's hands clasped on a lap

items.synopsis: Historic legislation is set to be introduced in Queensland today, with Hannah Clarke's parents praising the new protection for victims.

title.children: Lucy followed her husband's directions in hopes he'd love her more, until she realised she was being coercively controlled

image.altText: A close shot of Wong, wearing glasses and speaking, inside parliament house.

image.altText: A man in a cap and glasses.

items.synopsis: Alan Leslie Graham was 79 at the time he was last seen in April 2016 at Angepena Station during a prospecting trip to SA's far north, and the state's coroner is now trying to piece together his final movements from witness testimonies.

image.altText: Afghan men carry on their shoulders the body of a woman earthquake victim, wrapped in black cloth.

image.altText: A young woman wearing sunglasses looks out a car window

items.synopsis: Tasmania's public housing overcrowding rates are higher than the national average and continue to grow, with one family in Hobart's northern suburbs given priority status still waiting after four years.

title.children: Katlyn's been told she can't get a bigger house for her growing family, so she drives around looking for one

image.altText: A composite of two images of a woman wearing a futuristic-looking vest and wristbands at a festival, standing on grassland

items.synopsis: Haptic technology transmits sounds as different vibrations on the body. It carries new possibilities to experience sound for people who are Deaf or hard of hearing.

title.children: Haptic technology allows people who are Deaf to feel music. Could it be used for speech?

image.altText: A woman sits on a park bench and looks at her phone.

items.synopsis: The telecommunications watchdog releases its annual report card on the country's telcos, and while complaints are down across the board, there’s one notable exception — Optus.

image.altText: Silhouette of a man standing on a shoreline at sunset looking out at an oil rig on the ocean.

title.children: A 'double whammy' for fish — and humans — if climate targets are overshot

image.altText: A man looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Aboriginal people are considering what the Voice might mean for them, and if they want it at all. The ABC visited several regional communities in Queensland and listened. Here's what they had to say.

title.children: Fred has 'lost a lot of white friends' in the lead up to the referendum. He hopes they can reconcile their differences

image.altText: An elderly Indigenous woman standing in an outback savannah, looking behind the camera.

items.synopsis: Two Northern Territory Indigenous leaders are urging voters to think about how a Voice to Parliament could advocate for better living conditions in their remote communities, but support in these areas is by no means unanimous.

title.children: NT Indigenous elders appeal for Voice to address disadvantage, but remote scepticism is still high

image.altText: Elska Mia with her clear harp sits on backstage steps. She wears a glittery dress, pink lipstick and blue boots.

items.synopsis: Elska kept a dark chapter of her life hidden for years. Through her music, she's finally been able to tell that story.

image.altText: Ballarat swap meet attendees looking through goods at 2020 event

image.altText: Brahman with skin blemish

image.altText: Canoe sitting on grass in front of sunset and lake

items.synopsis: Dozens of schools across three states are desperately trying to come up with a plan B after a popular school camp venue was unable to secure insurance to host students.

image.altText: A small marsupial like a native rat crouches in the grass

items.synopsis: The critically endangered species has never been sighted before in NSW, despite traces of hair and scat being discovered in forests 30 years ago.

title.children: 'Holy grail' moment as small population of long-footed potoroos found for first time in NSW

image.altText: A young man skydiving

items.synopsis: A 17-year-old West Australian takes out the Guinness World Record for the fastest time solving a rotating puzzle cube, while freefalling at 200 kilometres per hour.
